awd_titl_txt: A Novel Cu/CNT Material System for Through Silicon Via Interconnects
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for research supporting the development of a new material system for micro/nanoelectronic interconnects. The material system under study is expected to overcome several issues associated with copper interconnects. This material system will make it possible to fabricate nanoscale interconnects that possess low electrical resistance and high mechanical strength to provide a robust next generation of nano-interconnects. Utilizing advanced micro/nanofabrication processes, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) will be grown inside through-silicon vias (TSVs) and a copper matrix will be added to enhance the density, strength and conductivity of the CNTs.  Electrical resistance of individual vias and daisy-chained vias will be measured and an analytical approach will be used to determine the preferred path of current and obtain insights on interface resistance of copper and CNT bundles. Mechanical strength will be investigated through bend tests and thermal expansion of wafers containing TSVs while the electrical resistance of TSVs will be monitored for resistance variation for failure detection. Finite element simulation will be used to verify and calibrate the experiments. Mechanical and thermo-mechanical fatigue durability will be examined. 

Interconnects are an essential component of any electronic system. In particular, TSVs are key interconnects necessary for fabrication of three-dimensional integrated circuits (3D-ICs). Therefore, advancements in the area of interconnects will enhance three dimensional (3D) integration of complex electronic devices. If successful, this research will result in a new material system that is capable of resolving several performance and reliability issues that exist with copper interconnects today, such as high resistivity at very small dimensions and electromigration. The research conducted in this study will lead to new directions taken in the manufacturing and fabrication of micro/nanoelectronic devices and systems by facilitating miniaturization of sub-systems and providing a path for a high-yield, high-volume manufacturing process.  Outreach activities include a college workshop for K-12 students, the recruitment of women and minorities into the research program in collaboration with the University of Alabama's LSAMP Program, and participation in an REU Site.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this project were to explore a novel idea of fabricating Cu-CNT composites for interconnect applications. The novelty of this idea lies on the originality of fabrication techniques that was proposed and nano-scale structural design which has the potential to deliver high conductivity, advanced multifunctional properties, better reliability and longer life for these interconnects. Over the span of this project, the proposed plan of fabrication was followed and vast amount of knowledge was generated that helped immensely with understanding the process itself, process control parameters and best approaches and practices, and final material characteristics and properties. The know-how and recopies that were generated during this project are documented and stored digitally and are available to scientists and engineers to apply in their processes and applications.

The knowledge generated under this project was disseminated throughout the course of this project through numerous journal and conference publications and patents. Below, we have listed some of the publications. Furthermore, several graduate and undergraduate students? education has been impacted by this award. One PhD student, Ibrahim Awad, obtained training on numerous equipment and experimental techniques in collaboration with MIT Microtechnology center. Furthermore, he developed computational skills such as finite elements analysis and molecular dynamics modeling simulations. An MS. Student Matthew Jordan conducted his experiments for his thesis partially under the funding of this project. He continued to receive his PhD from Georgia Institute of Technology and currently is a scientist at Sandia National Lab.  

Several other graduate and undergraduate students were also impacted positively. Another example is a female undergraduate student, Zakia Ahmed who received training on photolithography and other micro/nanofabrication techniques at University of Texas at Arlington. Zakia?s work was disseminated through an Research Experience for Undergraduate Symposium, Council for Undergraduate Research, Alexandria VA. Zakia is now pursuing her PhD at Virginia Tech in the area of Mechanical Engineering. Several other students have been trained and educated under the course of this project. Other examples of undergraduate students impacted by this project are: Garrison Frost (pursuing BS. to continue PhD at ASU, Samatha Brown (currently PhD student at UCONN), Jordan Miller (Engineer at Lockheed Martin), and several others.

Frost, G., and Ladani, L., Development of High Temperature Resistant Seed Layer for the Electrodeposition of Copper for Microelectronic Applications,Journal of Electronic Materials, Available online. (link)

Ladani, L., Metal-Carbon Nanotubes Composites Potential as Interconnects, Journal of Electronic Materials, Volume 48, Issue 1, pp 92?98 (Jan. 2019) (link)

Ladani, L., Copper-CNT Hybrid TSVs: Thermo-mechanical Stresses and Reliability Analysis, Int. J. Hi. Spe. Ele. Syst., 24, 1550006 (2015) [12 pages]. LINK 

Ladani, L., Awad, I., She, Y., Dardona, S. and Schmidt, W., Fabrication of Carbon Nanotube/Copper and Carbon Nanofiber/Copper Composites for Microelectronics, Materials Today Communications, Volume 11, June 2017, Pages 123?131. (Link)

Awad, I., and Ladani, L., Mechanical Integrity of Carbon Nanotube/Copper Based through Silicon Via for 3D Integrated Circuits: Multi-Scale Modeling Approach, Nanotechnology, 26 (48) (2015) 485705. LINK

Awad, I., and Ladani, L., Cohesive Zone Model for the Interface of Multi-walled Carbon Nanotubes and Copper: Molecular Dynamics Simulation, J. Nanotechnol. Eng. Med. 5(3), 031007 (Aug 01, 2014) (7 pages) Paper No: NANO-14-1056; doi: 10.1115/1.4029462. Link.

Awad, I, and Ladani, L., Interfacial strength between single wall Carbon Nanotubes and Copper material: Molecular Dynamics simulation, Journal of Nanotechnology in Engineering and Medicine, Nov. 2013, Vol. 4 / 041002-1. Link
